column2: Linux is a free and open-source operating system used in servers. Desktops. And embedded devices.
The kernel is the core of the operating system. It manages hardware and system resources.
The shell is a text-based interface that lets you run commands and interact with Linux.
Bash is the most common shell in Linux. It supports scripting and command execution.
Some basic Linux commands include ls. cd. pwd. mkdir. rm. cp. mv. and touch.
The ls command lists files and directories in the current folder. Use ls -l for details.
The cd command changes the current working directory. Example: cd Documents.
The pwd command prints the current working directory path.
The mkdir command creates a new directory. Example: mkdir new_folder.
The rm command deletes files or folders. Use rm -r for directories.
The cp command copies files or folders. Example: cp file.txt backup.txt.
The mv command moves or renames files. Example: mv old.txt new.txt.
The touch command creates an empty file. Example: touch notes.txt.
The cat command displays the contents of a file. Example: cat notes.txt.
Nano is a simple text editor for editing files in the terminal.
Vim is a powerful editor for advanced users. It supports modes and scripting.
The sudo command lets you run commands with administrator privileges.
Use sudo apt install <package> to install software on Debian-based systems.
Use sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade to update your system packages.
Good beginner-friendly Linux distros include Linux Mint. Ubuntu. And Debian.

column1: best linux distro for advanced users
column2: Advanced users often prefer Arch Linux or NixOS for customization and control.
Open source software is free to use. Modify. And distribute.
The terminal is a command-line interface to interact with the Linux system.
Linux is a great platform for programming. It supports many languages and powerful tools.

column1: best programming language for linux system
column2: Popular languages for Linux include C. Python. Bash. And C++. Each has its own strengths.

column1: linux kernel written in c language
column2: The Linux kernel is mostly written in C. With some parts in assembly language.
Linux was created by Linus Torvalds in 1991 as a free and open-source alternative to Unix.
Linux offers tools like gcc. make. gdb. nano. vim. and VS Code for development.
Python works very well on Linux. You can run scripts. Build apps. And use powerful libraries.

column1: c programming on linux kernel level
column2: C is used for low-level programming in Linux. Including kernel and system-level development.
Bash scripting helps automate tasks in Linux. It's widely used for system administration.
You can set up a Linux dev environment with gcc. Python. Git. And your favorite editor.
